text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
and CNBC today we had another
demonstration of the scale of the
challenges facing the new Obama
administration economically and
politically in the morning Treasury
Secretary Tim Geithner disclosed the
outlines of a broad multi-front attack
on the ongoing crisis facing the
nation's financial systems the plan
seeks to put as much as two trillion
dollars to work through four main
components one is new capital injections
for the nation's troubled banks those
deemed capable of surviving after
undergoing a stress test by regulators a
second element is dramatically expanded
lending by the Federal Reserve with the
goal of easing the flow of credit for
consumers and small businesses a third
is a new venture that seeks to use
taxpayer and private-sector money to
provide incentives for investors to buy
some of the so-called toxic assets that
have weighed down financial institution
since the housing bubble burst the
fourth is a plan to help more homeowners
avoid foreclosure by encouraging lenders
to write down mortgage principles as
ambitious as that plan is Geithner did
not ask Congress for more money beyond
the 350 billion dollars the Obama
administration already has as a result
of the financial bailout package enacted
last October the reason that bailout is
highly unpopular with average Americans
until the new administration can restore
confidence through steps such as
increased transparency and limits on
executive compensation lawmakers won't
provide any more money that's why
Treasury is leaning so heavily on the
Fed in the private sector right now a
few minutes after Geithner spoke the
Senate handed the Obama administration
of victory on its other major initiative
this week passing an economic stimulus
package of more than 800 billion dollars
but that package which president obama
calls critical to creating or saving up
to four million jobs still faces
difficult negotiations between the House
and Senate before final passage moreover
because the White House has been
frustrated in its quest for Republican
support so far the stimulus appears on
track to become a distinctly democratic
initiative that means Obama and his
party will dominate the credit if it
works and the blame if it doesn't
you
